Introduction

Pericarditis refers to inflammation of the pericardium, the protective sac surrounding the heart.

Pathophysiology



The pericardium consists of 2 parts: the outer fibrous pericardium and the inner serous pericardium.  The serous pericardium is composed of a parietal layer, which abuts the fibrous pericardium, and a visceral layer, which abuts the surface of the heart.  Between the parietal and visceral layers is the pericardial space, which normally contains a small amount of fluid that helps minimize friction between the heart and pericardium as the heart contracts.



Pericarditis results from a systemic or localized inflammatory process that involves the pericardium.  There is infiltration of inflammatory cells (eg, neutrophils, lymphocytes) into the pericardium, often with increased production of inflammatory fluid (ie, pericardial effusion).  The fluid can be fibrinous, serous, hemorrhagic, or purulent depending on the underlying source of inflammation.  Rapid or large-volume accumulation of pericardial fluid can increase the risk for cardiac tamponade.  Persistent inflammation can cause fibrosis and adhesions that restrict pericardial movement.

Etiologies



Common etiologies of pericarditis include (

):



  • Viral pericarditis:  Systemic viral infection is the most common cause of acute pericarditis.  Frequently implicated viruses include coxsackievirus, echovirus, influenza, and adenovirus.  Patients may have a prodrome of viral illness (eg, fever, malaise, respiratory symptoms, gastrointestinal symptoms), but in some cases pericarditis is the only apparent manifestation of viral infection.


  • Idiopathic pericarditis:  Often, the cause of acute pericarditis is never determined, and the etiology is deemed idiopathic.  Most of these cases are likely due to a viral infection that has not been definitively recognized.


  • Autoimmune pericarditis:  Systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, and scleroderma are frequent rheumatologic causes of pericarditis.


  • Uremic pericarditis:  Acute pericarditis can develop in patients with acute or chronic renal failure and elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN).  The BUN level at which pericarditis occurs is highly variable: some patients may develop pericarditis at BUN >60 mg/dL, but others can have much higher BUN levels without developing pericarditis.


  • Peri-infarction pericarditis:  This type of acute pericarditis results from local inflammation and typically occurs <4 days after myocardial infarction.  It is best prevented by early coronary reperfusion, which helps minimize myocardial necrosis.


  • Postâ€“cardiac injury syndrome (PCIS):  This is an immune-mediated pericarditis that occurs several weeks to months following myocardial injury.  Potential sources of injury include myocardial infarction, cardiac surgery or procedure, and trauma.  When the inciting injury is myocardial infarction, PCIS is often referred to as Dressler syndrome.


  • Bacterial/fungal pericarditis:  Tuberculosis is a common cause of pericarditis in regions where it is endemic.  Typical bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Neisseria meningitidis, are rare causes of acute pericarditis.  Systemic fungal infections, such as histoplasmosis and coccidioidomycosis, can also rarely involve the pericardium.


  • Malignant pericarditis:  This type of pericarditis most commonly occurs due to metastatic spread to the pericardium.  The most common malignancies causing pericarditis include breast cancer, lung cancer, and lymphoma.


  • Radiation therapy:  Acute pericarditis can occasionally develop within days or weeks of thoracic radiation therapy.

Clinical presentation



The classic clinical presentation of acute pericarditis includes (

figure 1
):



  • Chest pain:  This is the hallmark symptom of pericarditis, present in >95% of cases.  The pain is typically sharp, pleuritic, and substernal.  It may radiate to the neck, shoulders, or back and is typically worsened by deep inspiration.  The pain also characteristically worsens with lying flat and improves with sitting forward (positional).


  • Fever:  Low-grade fever is common, related to systemic inflammation or an underlying infectious process.


  • Pericardial friction rub:  A high-frequency grating or squeaking sound is best heard at the left sternal border with the patient leaning forward.  The rub is classically triphasic, with components heard during atrial systole, ventricular systole, and ventricular diastole.


  • Pericardial effusion:  Some degree of pericardial effusion is usually, but not always, present.  Pericardial effusion sufficient to restrict cardiac filling can lead to signs and symptoms of cardiac tamponade (eg, hypotension, tachycardia, pulsus paradoxus).

Diagnosis



  • Clinical evaluation:  A thorough history and physical examination, focusing on chest pain characteristics, positional exacerbation, and associated symptoms (eg, viral prodrome), are key to diagnosing pericarditis.


  • ECG (
    figure 2
    ):  Typical findings include diffuse ST-segment elevation with upward concavity (
    figure 3
    ) (caused by ventricular inflammation) and PR-segment depression (caused by atrial inflammation).  These changes are typically widespread and do not correspond to coronary artery distribution.  These ECG findings tend to be absent in uremic pericarditis because the inflammation does not affect the myocardium.


  • Chest x-ray:  Chest x-ray is often unremarkable but may show cardiomegaly if pericardial effusion is present.


  • Echocardiography (
    image 1
    ):  Transthoracic echocardiography is useful for assessing pericardial effusion and for detecting signs of tamponade, such as right atrial or right ventricular diastolic collapse.


  • Laboratory evaluation:  Inflammatory markers such as C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are typically elevated.  A complete blood count may show leukocytosis.


  • Pericardial fluid analysis:  If pericardial effusion is present, fluid analysis including cytology, Gram stain and culture, acid-fast bacilli stain and culture, and organism-specific PCR testing can be helpful.  Other parameters (eg, protein, cell count, lactate dehydrogenase) are rarely helpful (Light criteria for pleural fluid analysis does not apply to pericardial fluid analysis).

Management



For acute viral or idiopathic pericarditis, the recommended treatment is a combination of colchicine with an nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), usually ibuprofen or aspirin, over an NSAID alone, due to lower recurrence rates.  Indomethacin tends to cause more adverse effects than ibuprofen or aspirin and is reserved for when initial treatment is ineffective.  Glucocorticoids are reserved for patients with NSAID contraindications (eg, renal failure, late pregnancy) or specific conditions requiring glucocorticoids (eg, autoimmune pericarditis).  The lowest effective dose should be used, with a slow taper to reduce the risk of recurrent pericarditis.



For peri-infarction pericarditis, aspirin plus colchicine is preferred because it does not interfere with myocardial healing (NSAIDs other than aspirin may hinder scar formation).  Glucocorticoids and nonaspirin NSAIDs should generally be avoided unless pericarditis is persistent.



For pericarditis with an identifiable nonviral cause (eg, bacterial, malignant), treatment focuses on the underlying condition and may include drainage of pericardial effusion if necessary.  Patients with uremic pericarditis should undergo dialysis (once cardiac tamponade has been excluded).



Patients are typically advised to rest and avoid strenuous physical activity during the acute phase to minimize symptoms and reduce the risk of complications.

Complications



  • Cardiac tamponade:  Rapid or large-volume pericardial effusion can compress the cardiac chambers, leading to impaired diastolic filling, hemodynamic compromise, and potentially cardiac arrest.


  • Recurrent pericarditis:  This is defined as the recurrence of symptoms after an apparent resolution of acute pericarditis.  Recurrence may be seen in up to 15%-30% of cases.


  • Constrictive pericarditis:  Ongoing inflammation associated with chronic pericarditis or recurrent episodes of acute pericarditis can lead to pericardial fibrosis and restricted pericardial expansion.  This can impair diastolic filling of the heart chambers and cause right-sided heart failure.

Prognosis



The prognosis for acute idiopathic or viral pericarditis is generally good with appropriate treatment.  Most patients experience resolution of symptoms within a few weeks.  The prognosis for nonviral acute pericarditis is primarily driven by the underlying etiology (eg, malignancy, renal failure), which may carry a poor prognosis.  Cardiac tamponade is a potential cause of acute mortality, and constrictive pericarditis can lead to substantial chronic morbidity; however, these complications are relatively uncommon.

Summary



Acute pericarditis (
